content.title: Moretenders' Cocktail Crib, hangout for mixology enthusiasts

introduction.small: Discreet bar of the Beyoğlu neighbourhood, Moretenders' Cocktail Crib is nonetheless a major hangout for lovers of unusual cocktails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Moretenders' Cocktail Crib, hangout for mixology enthusiasts

paragraphs.text:
This small street of the lively Asmalimescit neighbourhood has retained the look and authentic charm of Istanbul. However, it hides a cocktail bar just as small but much trendier. At Moretenders' Cocktail Crib, mixology is given pride of place. Behind the counter, bartenders create about thirty signature cocktails, as well as a few classics with a twist. The menu stresses the originality of the drinks being prepared: you can read the name of each “moretender” under the cocktail they originated. In order to highlight the “homemade” feel another notch, some ingredients have even been supplied from the miniature garden located behind the establishment. Lovers of flowery cocktails, choose a Dead Mouse, with a tequila base, orange liquor, lemon juice, hibiscus and ginger – to be enjoyed in moderation of course. Hard to find a spot to sit and sip? It doesn't matter, as you will be lulled by the disco and house beats that attracted fellow patrons from the very first moment they arrived!

content.title: Mürver, wood-fired oven cuisine

introduction.small: In the heart of the trendy Karaköy neighbourhood, Mürver is a restaurant that enjoys unique views over the Bosporus and offers food prepared in its large mid-room fireplace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mürver, wood-fired oven cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Glowing embers redden amid the huge blue-tiled dome, and the contrast sets the tone for a dinner at Mürver, as the speciality of the restaurant is wood-fired cuisine. Everything is therefore braised, smoked, seared or slowly cooked for hours. Even though the menu is meat-oriented, everybody can get their share: steak, octopus, squid, vegetables... every ingredient (and most are produced in Anatolia) will be put to the fire test. Mimic regular customers and order a braised quail with spicy pumpkin and beetroot mash, or slow-cooked Thracian lamb served with apricot purée, salted yogurt and firik, a typical kind of wheat from Turkey. As the skies darkened and the sun goes down, choose among great Turkish wines and settle in one of the Ottoman-style armchairs of the patio. It overlooks the Topkapi Palace, so you will be able to enjoy an amazingly unobstructed view over the Bosporus.

content.title: Gourmet dürüms at Basta Street Food Bar

introduction.small: A duo of starred-chefs reinvents Istanbul street food, especially its hallmark dish, the dürüm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gourmet dürüms at Basta Street Food Bar

paragraphs.text:
As a distant cousin of the shish kebab, the dürüm is a stuffed flatbread commonly eaten on the streets of Istanbul. At Basta Street Food Bar, two chefs have decided to lend it some cachet. From the outside, the restaurant does not look like traditional fast food joints. It has more to do with a bistro, showcasing a blue-tiled counter and clear-wood high stools. In this small space, the two chefs apply high cuisine techniques learnt from the greatest, like Paul Bocuse and Alain Passard, to street food. The meat used to fill the dürüm is being cooked for a long time to enhance its flavours. Choose kuzu, lamb chops with a paprika and harissa-based yoghurt sauce, or the vejetaryen, with asparagus, artichoke and hummus. After that, you will not see street food in the same light again.

Made from fresh herbs and subtle mixed flavours, bartender Dede's concoctions delight the palate with a whirlwind of eccentric yet balanced aromas. To be convinced, try the Lovelorn, made from pomegranates and mastiba liquor!

The impressive menu offers you a sample of the most inventive preparations, in keeping with the soundscape, fluctuating between soul and funk, distilled with refinement without being deafening. If you are looking for a little more space, there is a lounge just a few steps down. On the menu: cocktails – to drink in moderation – and quieter music, given its tempo by the demands of the customers using Efendi's motto: “More, please!”

introduction.small: The ultramodern Alancha restaurant offers gourmet enthusiasts subtle and original cuisine.

Alancha delights all visitors from Besiktas irresistibly enticed by its cuisine, leaving for the time of a meal from the European part of Turkey and heading for Anatolia, its Asian side.

The restaurant has impeccable design made of wood, with warm colours and dim lighting, providing a very cosy overall feel. On the plates is a festival of flavours: from the seven Anatolian regions, Kemal Can Yurttas, the master of the house, and other regularly invited chefs make the most by reinventing local dishes, such as truffle mulhama, a traditional sausage-based recipe served with cornbread, the famous beef köfte, Anatolian-style and a few pistachio baklavas. For an unexpected gastronomic journey, head to Alancha, a crossroads of influence where the land and the sea, Asia, Greece and the Nordic countries dance merrily.

content.title: Alexandra, a cocktail with a view of the Bosphorus

introduction.small: In the heart of the Beşiktaş district, Alexandra Cocktail Bar offers a terrace with views and mysterious concoctions.

A stone's throw from Bosphorus, Alexandra proudly bears the title of the city's hippest cocktail bar, awarded by Istanbul's youth who love to gather there.

The establishment, all in woodwork and dim lights, is frequented especially at night, even if it serves breakfasts at the crack of dawn.

In the evening, behind the bar, bartender Osman Fethi lines up his recipes by the glass, including the Knock! Knock!, which is ordered by knocking on the counter twice.

Equally original, the rooftop offers a view of the Bosphorus so famous that the crowd is already rushing in the second it opens at 7:00 p.m. While waiting, go back downstairs and order a surprise cocktail whose preparation depends on the bartender's mood. On the weekends, DJs, including the unmistakable Yakuza, mix house sets, one after the other, until 3:00 in the morning. An evening hotspot in Istanbul, don't miss Alexandra!

content.title: Karaköy Lokantasi, a chic restaurant with divine mezze

introduction.small: In a street parallel to the popular Karaköy pier filled with little food stalls, Karaköy Lokantasi is a favourite restaurant to many locals.

paragraphs.text:
As you enter Karaköy Lokantasi, you will be immediately seduced by the beautiful interior. Though openly contemporary, the restaurant has preserved a local touch by using the wonderful turquoise blue of Turkish tiles. In the centre of the large dining room is a spiral staircase leading to another large dining room, giving the place the appearance of a French brasserie.

After greeting you at the entrance, the waitress leads you to your table stopping at the meze stall on the way. The menu, which changes daily, offers Ottoman cuisine with some creative touches. In addition to the cold or hot mezzes, try the manti – a kind of Turkish dumpling stuffed with lamb or ground beef and seasoned with spices - or izgara köfte, grilled meatballs typical of Istanbul cuisine. To finish on a sweet note, order a semolina pudding with cream. A delight!

content.title: The Beylerbeyi Palace, on the banks of the Bosphorus

introduction.small: Summer residence of the Ottoman sultans, the Beylerbeyi Palace will surprise you with its mix of Western and Oriental styles.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Beylerbeyi Palace, on the banks of the Bosphorus

paragraphs.text:
Dating back to the 19th century, the Beylerbeyi Palace was created by architect Sarkis Balyan. Designed to welcome sultans during their holidays, it has also become the residence of statesmen such as Tsar Nicholas II, King Edward VIII of England or Eugenie, wife of Napoleon III, Emperor of France. In Baroque architectural style, the palace, located on the banks of the Bosphorus, was built in white marble and stone. Composed of six lounges, 24 rooms, a large bathroom and a hammam, it has the characteristics of the traditional Turkish house, with a haremlik, reserved for women, and another, selamlik, reserved for men. An eclectic decoration completes the harmony of the place with splendid carpets, candelabras in Bohemian crystal, and Chinese, Japanese, French and Turkish porcelain. Do not miss a visit to the central salon, the blue room and the room with marquetry, considered the most beautiful rooms of the palace, then walk in the gardens with several stunning garden pavilions.

content.title: Dolmabahçe Palace, the last imperial residence

introduction.small: Like an Ottoman version of Versailles, Atatürk's last residence is a sumptuous palace that towers above the shores of the Bosphorus.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dolmabahçe Palace, the last imperial residence

paragraphs.text:
The spectacular Dolmabahçe Palace was commissioned by Sultan Abdülmecit I, who found Topkapi too old-fashioned. Construction started in 1843 and was completed in 1856. Inspired by European palace design, its Baroque style was very fashionable at the time.

Its long facade on the Bosphorus stretches over 248 metres. Inside, there are 285 incredibly opulent rooms including six steam rooms and 68 toilets. Its construction cost five million Ottoman gold pounds, the equivalent of 35 tonnes of gold, 14 of which were used in sheets to decorate the ceilings. A must see is the great throne room, lit with a 725-bulb chandelier, a gift from Queen Victoria.

Other wonders are the Baccarat crystal staircase, the gleaming marble, and, of course, the famous harem, with its subtle Mashrabiya. You'll notice that all the clocks are set to 9:05, in memory of Atatürk, who died at that time in his palace on 10 November 1938.

content.title: The Blue Mosque: bright and imperial

introduction.small: At the heart of Sultanahmet and facing the Hagia Sophia, this mosque, adorned with cascading domes and six minarets pointing to the heavens, rivals the Christian landmark in elegance.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Blue Mosque: bright and imperial

paragraphs.text:
Built under the reign of Sultan Ahmet I, between 1609 and 1616, this is the last of the imperial mosques. The building had to outdo its neighbour, the Hagia Sophia, and its rival, the holy mosque of Mecca. Thus, its six minarets, which angered the religious orthodoxy. To resolve the conflict, it was necessary to finance and build a seventh minaret in Mecca!

The Blue Mosque owes its name to the 20,000 tiles from Iznik adorning the walls. The sumptuous enamelled tiles are beautifully illuminated by spotlights, resulting in a bluish glow in the prayer room. Entrance to the mosque is limited to certain hours, to allow access to the faithful, who enter through the main door. As a tourist, you will be prompted to take the south gate and take off your shoes. Women should cover their head with a scarf.

content.title: Maçka Palas, combining elegance and modernity

introduction.small: Away from the tourist bustle, in the residential and trendy Nişantaşı district, the hotel combines the architecture of an Art Deco building with a resolutely avant-garde style.

Here, no garish colours, only shades of beige, brown, and chocolate, and noble materials such as wood, leather, and glass that can be found in the 90 rooms and suites, which offer discreet views of the city. A contemporary look is especially at work in the restaurant and the lounge bar, a popular location among Istanbulites for an evening drink. Equally trendy is the outdoor terrace and wine bar, accessible from the first days of spring.

Finally, to finish off, indulge in a moment of relaxation at the Spa and enjoy the beautiful outdoor swimming pool.

content.title: Futuristic meeting at Santralistanbul

introduction.small: Often compared to the Tate Modern and its Turbine Hall in London, Santralistanbul has been set up in a rehabilitated power plant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Futuristic meeting at Santralistanbul

paragraphs.text:
After having housed the first power plant of the Ottoman Empire and supplied electricity to the Turkish capital from 1911 to 1983, this 118,000 sqm industrial building was converted into not one but two museums: the Museum of Contemporary Art and the Museum of Energy. In addition, the vast building welcomes several other places to discover as you walk about, such as an amphitheatre and a concert hall.

The bar-restaurant is located in a former control centre, from where you will use the dizzying staircase down to the engine room. The Energy Museum is entirely dedicated to the history of electricity and gives you an opportunity to learn and have fun with experiments. Enjoy the shows, concerts – notably in jazz, various performances, debates, workshops and meet artists in this unique location, one of the most eclectic of the whole city.

content.title: Plunge into a Turkish bath

introduction.small: A veritable institution, the steam bath is part of the culture of Istanbul. Try the hammam experience in an authentic Ottoman monument of the 16th century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Plunge into a Turkish bath

paragraphs.text:
There are many Turkish baths across the city, from old to modern, each neighbourhood has its own. Several formulas and different services are offered: from a simple steam session to a massage followed by a Turkish coffee in the relaxation room. Three hammams are particularly worth a visit.

First is the most famous, the Cemberlitas Hamami, near the Grand Bazaar, built in 1584 by the architect Mimar Sinan. The architecture is magnificent: beautiful marble and mosaics, and two grandiose domes over the impeccable bathing rooms. Then there's Cagaloglu, always full since 1741. The staff is charming, and the oriental decor is made of white marble, pink mosaics, and ancient basins. Its stained-glass dome diffuses a warm light on the central platform.

Finally, Kılıç Ali Paşa Hamamı, also designed by Mimar Sinan in the 16th Century, was entirely renovated a few years ago. Its flamboyant marble and lavish bathing rooms are worthy of sultans and sultanas alike.

content.title: Hacı Bekir, delicious flavours

introduction.small: Don't leave Istanbul without tasting its famous Turkish delight, the recipe for which has endured since 1777.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hacı Bekir, delicious flavours

paragraphs.text:
The best Turkish delight in town, no doubt, is made by Haci Bekir, the famous confectioner who invented the recipe in 1777, upon returning from a pilgrimage to Mecca. The small gelatinous cubes are sprinkled with icing sugar and starch, flavoured with rosewater, and baptised “rahat lokum”.

More than two centuries and five generations later, the confectionery Haci Bekir created still exists, adored and appreciated in all countries of the former Ottoman Empire and beyond. The main shop, near the Grand Bazaar, has 18 different flavours. The classics are rosewater, mastic, and creamy Kaymak lokum. This unique delicacy, available in the winter months (heat and Turkish delight don't get along), should be eaten fresh. Along Turkish delights, kids will salivate looking at halvah, candies and other sugar almonds on display in shop's window.

introduction.small: Who wouldn't dream to sail along the Bosphorus, along white marble palaces, luxury hotels, and fishing villages?

It is by the sea that we discover the most romantic side of Istanbul, crossing the vibrant Bosphorus. A legendary strait that connects the Black Sea to the Sea of ​​Marmara, the delta cuts Istanbul in half, and is in itself an attraction.

The people of Istanbul, like the sultans who took up residence as early as the 19th century in the Dolmabahçe Palace, come to its shores in the early sunlight for dinner, to have a drink, relax, and party. To hear the famous ‘siren song' embark on one of the boats that cross the strait from Eminönü to its mouth at the Black Sea.

The eye candy is stunning: palaces, fortresses, traditional wooden Ottoman houses, the Bosphorus Bridge, the Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge, and countless fishing boats with well filled nets. Whether travelling on a short cruise, a long cruise, or by ferry, you will not be disappointed!

content.title: The Mosque of Suleiman the Magnificent

introduction.small: Built atop one of the seven hills of Istanbul, Süleymaniye Mosque is the most beautiful and majestic of the imperial mosques

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Mosque of Suleiman the Magnificent

paragraphs.text:
Built in 1550 in honour of Suleiman the Magnificent, the fourth Ottoman sultan in Istanbul and the tenth of the Ottoman dynasty, the Süleymaniye Mosque impresses as much by its extraordinary proportions as by the harmony of its architecture.

Totally renovated, it now radiates all its glory. The vast prayer hall, topped with 53-metre-high dome on four pillars, is a marvel of transparency. The light from the 138 windows makes the sumptuous stained glass and Iznik ceramics sparkle. Admire the carved wooden doors: inlaid with mother of pearl and ivory, these are works of rare craftsmanship of precision. The structure was built by the famous Ottoman architect Mimar Sinan, who sought to surpass the prowess of the Greek architects who designed Hagia Sophia by giving Suleymaniye an architectural gem worthy of his reign.

This is one of the most popular mosques in the city and attracts as many faithful as the Blue Mosque. So, avoid peak hours.

content.title: Venture to the Adaları, the Princes' archipelago

introduction.small: Take a stunning hour-long journey by boat from Istanbul to the favourite vacationing spots of Istanbul's rich families in the 19th and 20th centuries.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Venture to the Adaları, the Princes' archipelago

paragraphs.text:
Located in the Marmara Sea, about 20 kilometres from Istanbul, the archipelago is served by boat several times a day from Kabatas, on the European side, and from Kadikoy and Bostanci, on the Asian side.

Ideally, put a day or two aside to bask in their retro charm, enjoy the natural surroundings, and swim in the turquoise waters. Their name ‘Princes' Islands' was given to them during the Byzantine period, when disgraced aristocrats were exiled here. In the 19th century they were transformed into posh beach resorts, popular with Greek, Jewish, and Armenian merchants, and wealthy Istanbul Ottomans. They settled on the four largest islands Büyükada, Heybeliada, Burgazada and Kinaliada and built sumptuous wooden mansions (yalis).

The largest, the island of Büyükada, is the favourite of Istanbul's wealthiest families, many of whom have their summer residences there. No cars are allowed, only bicycles and horse-drawn carriage taxis (fayton).

content.title: Stroll on Galata Hill and visit the old Genoese tower

introduction.small: For centuries the tallest building in the city, the Galata Tower offers striking views over the south districts, where many of Istanbul's wonders are gathered.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stroll on Galata Hill and visit the old Genoese tower

paragraphs.text:
On a clear day, the view from the top of the tower is spectacular. All the major sights of Istanbul and the Princes' Islands are within its ken. Built by Genoese merchants in the 13th century, this cylindrical tower with conical roof rises to a height 68 metres like a sentinel at the edge of town. Visible from all quarters, it dominates the northern shore of the Golden Horn. Now restored, it has a lift that leads to the terrace and its 360° panoramic view over the city and hills.

Enjoy a tour through the chic winding streets of Galata, filled with restaurants, tearooms, and small galleries. Recently, designers have begun to invest in the area, yet another reason to go window shopping! content.title: Step into the sultan's shoes at Topkapi Palace

introduction.small: Palace of the Ottoman Empire sultans for more than four centuries, this architectural gem of dazzling luxury was the scene of numerous intrigues.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Step into the sultan's shoes at Topkapi Palace

paragraphs.text:
A UNESCO World Heritage Site, Topkapi Palace, a city within the city, overlooking the Golden Horn, the Bosphorus, and the Marmara Sea, welcomed the sultans and their families from 1459 to 1863.

Visiting this Arabian Nights palace gives you an idea of ​​the refined lifestyle of the rulers. Passing through the Imperial Door, you cross the courtyard and confront the splendour of the seraglio. The most lavish rooms are those of the Treasury, the Imperial Council, and, of course, the phantasmal harem, which was once inaccessible to all but the imperial family and the concubines of the sultan. Take time to admire the wall tiles and the carved Mashrabiya, which provide a marvellous oriental flavour to your visit.

To make the most of the magic of the place, try to get here when it opens or at the very end of the day; there are fewer tourists at these times, the light is softer, and the heat is less overwhelming.

content.title: Literary visit to the bohemian neighbourhood of Istanbul

introduction.small: Stroll through the colourful streets of Cihangir, where antique dealers, artists, and writers hang out, and stop in at Orhan Pamuk's incredible Museum of Innocence.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Literary visit to the bohemian neighbourhood of Istanbul

paragraphs.text:
This amazing space in the Çukurcuma neighbourhood of the Beyoğlu district is a must. Turkey's most famous contemporary writer, Orhan Pamuk, winner of the 2006 Nobel Prize, envisioned this highly original space based on his novel of the same name: each display contains everyday items referring to a different chapter of the book, which takes in the years 1950-1970 in Istanbul, and tells the story Kemal, a well-off Istanbulite, who falls in love with his impoverished cousin. The museum displays the artefacts of their love story.

After this literary parenthesis, explore the antique shops on Çukurcuma Street. The picturesque, pedestrian street is filled with nice cafés, designer shops, and fashion boutiques. Try and wander around aimlessly to better enjoy the surroundings and remember that the Bosphorus is never far away.

paragraphs.text:
For ten years, contemporary art centres have been popping up everywhere in the city, thanks in part to rich industrialists and distinguished collectors who lend their works to foundations and subsidise art projects.

In 2005, the Istanbul Modern was created, financed by the Eczacibasi family. Superbly located on the docks in Karaköy in a former naval warehouse, the museum has over 8,000 square metres of clear, uncluttered exhibition space.

The permanent exhibition on the first floor is devoted to modern and contemporary Turkish artists. The ground floor has temporary installations and exhibitions by local and international artists. content.title: Whirling dervishes and the mystic dance

introduction.small: Discover the enlightening history of whirling dervishes and attend a full-scale ceremony at the Galata Mevlevi Museum.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Whirling dervishes and the mystic dance

paragraphs.text:
This former convent was built in 1491 to host the Mevlevi lodge, an order of dervishes founded in the 13th century under the Ottoman Empire. The Sufi brotherhoods, faithful to the origins of Islam, emphasise the unity of humanity before God. His disciples communicate with the latter by a form of prayer, accompanied by music, body movement, and quotes from the Koran. Dervish orders were banned in 1925 by Kemal Atatürk because of their conservatism.

It has since been re-established, but there are very few practitioners. Whirling dervish ceremonies are held on Saturdays and Sundays at 5:00 p.m. at the Galata Mevlevi Museum. Stay completely silent: it is a mystical moment, shared in communion, and selflessness is supposed to promote contact with the divine.

The museum houses a room of the order of dervishes, which displays clothes, turbans, and musical instruments. There is a small, very beautiful cemetery in the courtyard.

content.title: Turkish coffee, or nothing!

introduction.small: The coffee that was invented by the Ottomans several hundred years ago can still be found. Their original recipe is still the favourite.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Turkish coffee, or nothing!

paragraphs.text:
The first coffee house opened in Istanbul in 1554. Today, you will find one on every street corner. Trendy, traditional, classy or local, the recipe is the same. Neither soluble nor filtered, it is served as a concentrated decoction, with sugar added at the time of preparation. Turkish coffee is prepared in a special copper pan with a narrow spout and a long handle. When the foam appears and the liquid boils, it's ready. Immediately placed in a mocha cup, the brew, thick and full-bodied, is drunk in two sips.

Here is our selection of addresses to enjoy a cup of coffee with a Turkish twist: the famous Pierre Loti Café, in a traditional house where the novelist loved contemplating the Golden Horn; The Sunday and its Julius Meinl coffee, served only at the bar a charming place to spend time facing the Teşvikiye mosque; the House Cafe in the Ortaköy district, one of eight design House Cafe addresses of the same name, with magnificent views of the Bosphorus.

content.title: Colourful escape to Fener and Zeyrek

introduction.small: These two quaint neighbourhoods, lined with old houses, are mostly inhabited by Istanbulite fishermen. To discover without delay!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Colourful escape to Fener and Zeyrek

paragraphs.text:
Overlooking the Golden Horn, beyond Sultanahmet and its waves of tourists, nestle the historic neighbourhoods of Fener and Zeyrek. They are close enough to each other that you can explore both of them by foot in an afternoon.

Start in Zeyrek, a UNESCO World Heritage Site for its authentic wooden houses. These buildings are among the oldest in the city, with some konaks, homes dating back to the Ottoman Empire. Scattered in the steep streets and long abandoned, they are currently being restored. A little further along, you come cross the square of the Old Women's Market, a lively spot with many food shops.

Head next towards the Fatih district, where the historic neighbourhood of Fener is located. Here, in these very picturesque and charming streets, you will find historic houses of wood, numerous Orthodox churches, and synagogues. Formerly populated by Fanariots, descendants of the Byzantine aristocracy, it is now a modest and quaint district, where children play in the streets and fishermen conduct business.

The hotel offers all the services of a luxury hotel: spa, steam room, fitness centre, lush garden with swimming pool, and helipad. Food lovers can feast at one of three restaurants. The Ottoman cuisine at Tugra is positively scrumptious.

content.title: The venerable Hagia Sophia

introduction.small: From the top of its dome it has seen centuries of history. Basilica under the Byzantine Empire, mosque after the fall of Constantinople, it is the symbol of Istanbul.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The venerable Hagia Sophia

paragraphs.text:
Jewel of Christianity and emblem of Byzantine power, Hagia Sophia dazzles you with its beauty and exceptional size. Consecrated in 537 during the reign of the Byzantine Emperor Justinian, it was for a thousand years the largest religious structure ever built.

The materials and precious stones were transported from far away, stripped from the Temple of Artemis in Ephesus, one of the seven wonders of the ancient world. To put it plainly, this masterpiece has no equal. A basilica first, and then a mosque after the conquest of Constantinople in 1453, it has been a museum since 1935. The view from inside of its magnificent 56-metre high dome rising to the sky will leave you breathless.

The gold mosaics that once covered it are now reduced to fragments, but you can still see other priceless pieces, including the four most famous other mosaics: Christ Pantocrator above the Imperial Gate; The Virgin and Child and the Deesis in the south gallery, as well as The Virgin Mary. Wander, float, and let yourself be intoxicated by this grandiose architecture, all of which is illuminated by sparkling chandeliers.
